JUNIORS DEFEAT SENIOR TEAM
REMEMBER THE
Class of 1916 Wins Interclass Debate
Thos. J.Tingley's Rebuttal a Feature.
Steinbach Wins Adams Medal.

ANNUAL CONCERT and DANCE

The eighteenth annual interclass
debate was won by the juniors on
Friday night in McCoy Hall. The
Adams medal for public speaking
was awarded to Alexander Alan
Steinbach.
The first speaker in the Adams
contest was Roger Clarence Heimer, who delivered Lodge's "Our
Navy at Santiago." Heimer spoke
in a clear and emphatic voice, and
on the whole made a very good impression. Alexander Alan Steinbach, who followed him, showed a
greater familiarity with the finer
points of public speaking, and his
selection, Senator Thurston's speech
on "The Monroe Doctrine," enabled
him to use his very effective voice
to the best advantage. Charles
Webster Chesley, the last speaker,
gave Holmes'"The Soldier's Faith"
in a manner which, while not as
striking as Steinbach's, showed evidences of careful preparation.
The subject of the debate between
the seniors and juniors was, "Resolved, That a policy of colonial
expansion is desirable for a modern
State."
The Class of 1915, whose team
was composed of Joseph T. Bartlett, Jr., Charles S. Weech, .Avra
M. Warren (chairman) and Millard Eiseman (alternate), with
Moses Baroway as adviser, upheld
the affirmative.
The negative was defended by
the Class of 1916, represented by
Alfred Niles, Jr., Harrison C. Coffin, Thomas T. Tingley (chairman)
and Dorsey Richardson (alternate),
with Clarence W. McDowell as adviser.
The debate was opened by Mr.
Bartlett, who gave a careful explanation of the subject and outlined
the affirmative's plan of attack. The
first speaker on the negative was
Mr. Coffin, who, with very little introduction, plunged into the subject
and developed his points in a clear
and emphatic manner. Mr. Weech,
the second speaker on the affirmative, showed a thorough knowledge
of the subject. He was followed
by Mr. Niles, the second speaker
on the negative, who briefly and
plainly completed the arguments of
his side and presented a summary
of their entire position.
As rebuttal for the affirmative,
Mr. Warren attacked the arguments of the opposing side in a
clever manner, which pleased the
audience. Mr. Tingley; the closing
speaker, knew his subject and presented his facts and counter-argu-

IN FAVOR OF ARMED CITIZENRY

COTILLON TO BE GALA AFFAIR

Pres. Goodnow Approves Suggestion of
Pres. Hibben of Princeton that Students Receive Military Training.

Second Dance to Last Until Twelvethirty----President and Mrs. Goodnow Will Attend Event.

Military training for students in
American universities and colleges
is favored by President Goodnow.
In a letter sent to the New York
Times, he advocates the suggestion
made by President Hibben, of
Princeton, and says that this suggestion is quite in line with the idea
of "a citizenry trained in arms,"
voiced by President Wilson.
President Goodnow's letter was
as follows:
"I have your letter of January 13,
relative to the suggestion made by
President Hibben that military
training should be introduced into
the University. I personally approve
of the suggestion, believing that in
such a way we should aid in providing for the defense of the country without resort to a large regular army. I feel that this suggestion is quite in line with the idea of
'a citizenry trained in arms,' voiced
by President Wilson.

The second cotillon of the season, which will be held on the evening of Friday, February 12, promises to be a most gala occasion. All
of the devices which, in conjunction with the presence of a certain
orchestra leader not unknown to
fame, have combined to make past
cotillons successful, will be in operation on this eventful night, while,
if rumor is to be credited, there
will be added certain innovations
calculated to make the character of
the entertainment even more distinctive than usual.
The most interesting deviation
from the cotillons of the past will
be the presence of President Goodnow, who, with Mrs. Goodnow, has
consented to lend this very official
recognition to the occasion. The
President has warned the committee, however, that his acceptance of
their invitation is conditional, as he
is unwilling to exhibit publicly his
rendition of the deceptive fox-trot.
Even on these disappointing terms,
however, the acceptance of the invitation is regarded as a precedent
that may go down to future years
of terpsichorean artists yet unborn.
As was the case at the opening
dance of the season, the cotillon
will begin at 8.30, and continue till
half-past twelve, indicating that the
triumph of the Board in securing
an extension of the time limit for
the last affair was by no means a
temporary one. Supper will be
served at i i o'clock, in accordance
with the usual practice, and will
be followed by a continuance of the
"joy unconfined" that, since time
immemorial, has graced all similar
occasions.
It is particularly desired that,
since the time limit has been extended, all who plan to attend the
cotillon will come early and leave
promptly at the closing hour. Such
a course of action in respect to the
latter stipulation will undoubtedly
meet with the high favor of the
numerous gentlemen in waiting
whose task it is to close up the
building when the last belated reveller has departed.

"FRANK

J.

GOODNOW,

"President Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md."
The New York Times received
many letters from noted educators
throughout the country, asked by
that newspaper to give their views
on the subject.
President Goodnow was among
those who approved the suggestion
of President Hibben, of Princeton.
Dr. Hibben, in his letter to the
Times, says:
"Military strength which is available but not visible, and therefore incapable of ostentatious display, will
enable us to meet any critical emergency that may arise, and at the
same time protect us from the domination of a military .caste and a military policy. This plan of intensive
training of our college men does not
in any way tend to increase our
standing army."
This is not the first time Dr.
Goodnow has advocated college athletic training. It will be recalled
that at the opening reception of the
Young Men's Christian Association
last October, President Goodnow
won favor by announcing himself
a convert to athletics.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
MARSHALL SAILS FOR THE WAR
Despite Failure of His First Attempt
He Finally Leaves on Lusitania
to Enlist With Allies.

Julian Marshall, Hopkins graduate, member of the championship
1913 lacrosse team and assistant lacrosse coach, has left for the front.
Mr. Marshall, after being detained
by the Baltimore Custom House officials and prevented from leaving
on the Vulga, finally sailed on January 30 on the Lusitania.
The captain of the Vulga, in order to assist Mr. Marshall in carrying out his plans to join the English army, agreed to hire him as
purser for the trip to England in
consideration of the nominal salary
of one shilling a month. Mr. Marshall was ready to sail on the Vulga
last Tuesday morning, when the
customs officials noticed that the
purser was to receive practically no
salary.
They investigated, and
learning that Mr. Marshall's sole
object in sailing was to join the
English army, they refused him
passage. Consequently, the Vulga
had to sail a day late, and without
the prospective soldier.
He had volunteered after the outbreak of the war to join the Canadian expeditionary forces, but
they would only accept the services
of bona fide Canadians. Mr. Marshall, though born in the United
States, and though he has lived most
of his life here, is of English family, and is himself a registered English subject; therefore, the unsuccessful outcome of his attempts only
made him more determined to go
and fight for England.
Mr. Marshall expects to go directly to London, where he will stay
with relatives. There he will present letters of introduction and
recommendation to several high
military officials, after which at
least six months' training at one of
the officers' training schools will be
necessary before he can hope to see
service at the front; but unless there
is an unexpected turn of affairs, the
war will then still be in progress
and he will have a chance to fight
for his country.
On January' 23, after the freshman-sophomore track meet, Mr.
Marshall practiced with the lacrosse
team and performed his regular
duties as assistant coach. He has
shown marked determination to
carry out his plans and is extremely
optimistic about his venture, having made promises to many of his
friends to bring them back German
helmets as souvenirs.
While his many Hopkins friends
will miss him, they are all proud
of his nerve and determination and
wish him the best of success in attaining the goal of his ambitions.

HULLABALOO WORK PROGRESSES

LECTURES ON POLITICAL THEORY

1915 Board Has Much Copy, Including
Jokes and Poems - Business Department Needs More "Ads."

Prof.Dunning,Schouler Lecturer,Tells of
Burke, Mette, von Holler, Bentham
and Rusten—Two More Talks.

During the last few weeks, work
has been progressing with some
rapidity on the 1915 Hullabaloo.
At each weekly meeting the editors
have had a quantity of material to
read. A large number of original
articles, including jokes, sketches
and poems, has been reviewed by
the Board and reserved for future
use.
The photographic department has
made great progress during the last
month. All of the class pictures
have been taken; the Hullabaloo
Board's picture, THE NEws-LETTER
Board, some of the fraternities and
several other groups have also been
taken.
Mr. Baker, '15, wishes the pictures to be taken as soon as possible, because the sooner the proof
is in the hands of the photographer
the sooner he can give it to the
engravers, and in this way the best
possible results can be obtained for
the cuts that are to appear in the
Hullabaloo.
The pictures of the spring teams
cannot be taken yet, but as soon as
the teams get out of doors the photographer will be called into service. Most of the individual pictures of the members of the senior
class have been taken, but there are
still some delinquents. If all of
these pictures are not in by the first
of March the Board does not propose to hold up the edition for the
tardy seniors.
The underclasses have not as yet
handed in very much material that
might be used. There is very little
time left and all articles have to be
sanctioned by the Board before they
appear in the book.
As has been stated before, the
Board this year is going to have a
certain number of books printed and
n,o more. In order to be sure of
getting a book each man should
sign one of the subscription blanks
that any of the class presidents will
furnish. By paying- before February 25, 1915, fifty cents can be
saved.
The advertising manager announces that the $450 mark has
been passed. To make the book a
complete success, more than a thousand dollars' worth is required. If
each man in the University would
get one ad, the goal desired could be
reached. A liberal commission of
20 per cent, is paid on all advertisements. The firms who have posters
on the Hullabaloo wall should be
patronized. The men who expect
to get out a year book during the
next few years should try to throw
trade to these firms, in this way
gaining their "good will" and perhaps an advertisement for their
own book.

• Prof. William A. Dunning of
Columbia University delivered on
last Monday and Tuesday in McCoy Hall the first of his series of
lectures under the James Schouler
Foundation on the general subject
of "Early Phases of Nineteenth
Century Political Theory."
The topic of Monday's lecture
was "Conservative and Reactionary
Doctrine," while that discussed on
Tuesday was "British Utilitarianism." The method of treatment
was very comprehensive, for instead of merely generalizing, Dr.
Dunning considered intimately the
work and thought of the leading
minds of the period.
The two great movements of the
dawn of the nineteenth century
were the growth of nationalities,
and the rise of written constitutions. Opposed to these innovations there were, however, throughout Europe a number of reactionaries, conspicuously Edmund Burke
in England, Joseph Mette in
France, and Ludwig von Holler in
Germany.
There was not one of the three
who believed in the rights of the
people as they were being asserted
in the revolutions. Burke boldly
attacks them in his "Reflections on
the French Revolution," while
Mette is almost mediaeval in
thought. Von Holler's philosophy
is of a different type. To his mind
the only free man is he who depends on no one, but these persons
gather around them dependents who
form the State. Monarchy is thus
the earliest form of society. When
all Europe was ringing with the
Rights of Man and the Contract
Theory, nothing could have been
more reactionary than the opinions
of these men and their disciples.
A different group of philosophers
was considered on Tuesday by Professor Dunning; a group whose
chief exponents were Jeremy Bentham and his pupil John Rusten.
Utilitarianism, or the greatest good
for the greatest number, was the
doctrine expounded by them. Naturally they were opposed to the
general views of the time, for they
held that "the essence of the State
is merely the habit of conformity."
"Yet, whatever we may think of
utilitarianism," Dr. Dunning concludes, "it is refreshing amidst the
other theories of the time."
There are still two more lectures
of the series which will be delivered
on Monday and Tuesday, February i and 2; the topics being "The
Philosophy of Constitutionalism"
and "The Philosophy of Nationalism."

Rain may fall upon the just, but
the unjust usually have the, other
fellows' umbrellas.

William, why can't we have an
automobile like other people?"
"Because, my dear, I'll have to
put a new roof on the house before
it will hold a mortgage."

TRACK SQUAD STRENGTHENED

THE PANAMA LECTURE POPULAR

Men Getting into Shape for Heavy Indoor
Schedule--Hopkins to Be Represented in Important Meets.

Record Crowd Taxed McCoy Hall to
Hear Mr. Fisher Lecture— Featured
by Excellent Stereopticon Views.

The strength of the track squad
was greatly augmented last week
by the appearance of two of last
year's stars, who up to this time
had been unable to practice with
the squad. The squad is unusually
large now, though composed mostly of "green" material. The men,
however, are working regularly and
are fast getting into shape for the
hard indoor season, which will begin Saturday, February 13, with
the George Washington games. It
is proable that a comparatively
small number of men will be sent to
this first meet, as it is not to be a
very large affair. The principal
event for Hopkins will be a one-mile
relay race with Catholic University.
On the other hand, a large team
will be entered in the Fifth Regiment games, held here the following week. There will be at least
two relay races for Hopkins, in addition to the regular open events.
An important new feature of these
games will be a South Atlantic intercollegiate one-mile relay, in which
teams will be entered by Virginia,
Georgetown, Richmond University,
Washington and Lee, Hopkins, and
likely other members of the association. Among the colleges sending
teams to this meet, Princeton and
Pennsylvania figure prominently.
The next week (February 27)
a large team will be sent to the
Georgetown games at Washington.
As Hopkins won this annual contest last year, they have a reputation to live up to. Somewhat later,
a relay team will be sent to take
part in the Meadowbrook meet at
Philadelphia.
Owing to their victory last spring,
Hopkins has been raised another
class in the Penn Relays. They
now stand in Class I, with Columbia, Syracuse, Ohio State, Virginia and Georgetown. The next
step is into the championships.

To Mr. Frederick Vining Fisher
falls the honor of being the most
popular lecturer of the year. His
illustrated lecture on "The PanamaPacific Exposition" last Wednesday
afternoon brought out a crowd
which strained the capacity of McCoy Hall. Before he had begun
to speak it was necessary to lock
the doors in order to prevent overcrowding of the building.
Known as lecturer, author and
traveler, Mr. Fisher has been enlisted as manager of the Bureau of
Lectures of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition. In this role
he is endeavoring to interpret
America, to open a vision of the
greatness of our continent, to disclose its scenic beauties, and, not
least of all, to awaken in his hearers the desire to attend this year
the two expositions in the West.
Westward by means of the stereopticon and amid a seemingly irrepressible flow of ultrapoetic description Mr. Fisher took his audience
from Colorado, seven times the size
of Switzerland, and ten times as
beautiful, to the Grand Canyon in
Arizona. Thence he led the way
across prairies, rich in grain, to
the Yellowstone Park, America's
playground, where he featured the
Old Faithful geyser, "old when
Adam was a boy." Then, in picture, he showed the Chasm of the
Yellowstone, the Cascades, and, at
last, California, the land of great
trees, of the palm and poppy; the
land of perpetual summer, yet from
whose valleys "winters are ever seen
hovering on the peaks."
It is here that two expositions are
to be held this year, to celebrate,
not a national, but an international
event. One will be at San Diego,
the other at San Francisco. But
Mr. Fisher pointed out that it is
to the latter, held in the City of
Dreams, that all eyes are turned,
for, as lie said, it bids fair to rival

THE NEWS-LETTER takes great
pleasure in announcing the election
of the following men to positions
on the editorial staff:
William S. Merrick,'15.

George F. Ludington,'16.

John Saulsbury Short.

an emergency and always full of
opportune ideas, most of which he
put into effect with remarkable success. THE NEWS-LETTER owes its
present healthy condition equally as
much to Mr. Short as to any of
the foregoing editors who brought
it up to the status of an up-to-date
college weekly.
The present board of editors
wishes, therefore, by means of this
editorial, to thank Mr. Short for all
that he has done for the welfare of
the paper, and publicly to express
their appreciation of the sincerity
and good-will with which he carried
on the work with them, feeling that
they found in him not only an
editor-in-chief of eminent ability,
but also a friend who largely made
possible the existing harmonious
relations among those connected
with the staff.
THE NEWS-LETTER is very happy
to take advantage .of this opportunity to wish Mr. Short decided
success in all of his future undertakings, and especially to extend to
him the best wishes possible for
continued good fortune in his work
on the 1915 Hullabaloo.

NATURAL LIGHT IN GILMAN HALL

MUSICIANS ARE IN GOOD SHAPE

An Improved System of Daylight Illumination Will Cut Down Amount of
Electricity Used for Lighting.

Singers and Instrumentalists Holding
Final Rehearsals -Attractive Trips
and Town Concerts to Be Given.

One thing which impresses every
visitor to Gilman Hall is the splendid natural illumination of the
building. Every nook of the reading-room is flooded with light; offices and classrooms are bright and
cheery, and even the blind corridor
in the basement is not without its
quota of light, which comes through
the postoffice windows.
This is in distinct contrast with
architecture of earlier days. The
same contrast can be seen between
the City Hall and Court House in
this city. An abundance of artificial illumination is necessary in all

The Board of Managers of the
Musical Clubs have been busy during the past week completing arrangements for the McCoy Hall
concert, which will be given on
Tuesday, February 9.
Several hundred tickets have been
mailed to members of the faculty
and alumni from whom the Board
expects assistance. All members of
both clubs have been given tickets
to distribute. Tickets will also be
on sale at the University postoffice.
The price of the ticket (one dollar) also includes the dance which
follows the concert.
The leaders of both clubs have
been holding rehearsals daily and
the indications are that the clubs
will be in excellent condition to give
the first concert of the season,
which will be held on February 3
at the Phipps Psychiatric Clinic of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital. The
present plan of the leaders is that
all members of both clubs who hope
to take the trips must be present at
this concert and by the merits of
the work of the men at this concert
the squad will be picked to go to
Western Maryland.
On February 5, a concert will be
given at Western Maryland Col-,
lege at Westminster, where some
attractive methods of advertising
have been tried out.
The McCoy Hall concert, coming
as it does on the ninth, directly
preceded by these three preliminary
engagements, should be a success.
in every particular.
On February 16, a concert will
be given in this city at Odd Fellows' Hall, under the auspices of
the Girls' Guild of the First English Lutheran Church. An informal dance will follow' the concert.
Tickets may be secured at fifty cents
each from P. K. Bell.
Several more trips and local
concerts will be included in the
schedule.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 1, 1915.

JOHNS HOPKINS WILL HAVE AN
EHXIBIT AT SAN FRANCISCO FAIR

NEW MACHINERY INSTALLED IN
POWER PLANT AT HOMEWOOD

It was announced last week that
Johns Hopkins will send an exhibit
to the Panama-Pacific Exposition.
It will consist of drawings, made
by one of the consulting architects,
of the new Homewood buildings
and of the whole plans of the future
home of the University.
In addition to these drawings,
several pictures of historical interest
to the University will be exhibited.
Among these is a photograph of the
original deed of Homewood, which
was discovered lying loose in a record book at Annapolis several years
ago. A photograph of this deed
was presented to the University
about five years ago by Mrs. Hester
Dorsey Richardson, and has since
hung in the President's private
office.
The Hopkins exhibit will be hung
in the Maryland Building, along
with the historical exhibit which
will be housed there. It is interesting to note that the Maryland
Building is an exact replica of
Homewood, which is considered to
be the most perfect typical colonial
mansion in the State.

The new power plant at Homewood is now in operation. During
the past week the temporary lines
which had been run in by the Gas
and Electric Company were removed and the lighting of the buildings, together with the running of
the machinery in the shop, was
taken over entirely by current generated in the power-house.
An interesting feature of the
change was the charging of the
storage batteries. These batteries
completely fill a room which is
about fifteen by thirty-five feet and
they are used to meet any need for
current which may arise at night—
it being planned to run the dynamos
only during the day. In order to
give these batteries their initial
charge, it was necessary to run the
Westinghouse generator continuously for thirty-six hours.
During this time both the turbine
and the dynamos behaved splendidly, and those in charge were well
pleased with the results of the run.
Work on the installation of the
Corliss, Diesel, Foss and other special engines for test purposes is
well under way, and they will soon
be ready for use.
The ice machine is now being installed in the south end of Machinery Hall, while in the other end
many of the motors and other electrical apparatus have been put in
place.
The testing machines for the
civil engineering department are
in the "L" wing of the Hall and
are now ready for use.
Progress made thus far in equipping this building indicates that it
will not be long before the department of engineering is completely
settled in its new building.

SPOONING CONDEMNED
BY UNIVERSITY SPEAKER

Dancing and spooning as pastimes for college students were dealt
a hard blow by Dr. M. J. Exner, a
- member of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christion Association, when he addressed
three hundred men of the University of Washington recently, on "A
Rational Fight for Self-Mastery in
the Sphere of Sex."
"The modern dance is inexpedient," he said. "There are certain
conditions under which I would
consider dancing proper, but unless
these are observed, you have no
right to indulge in dancing."
The conditions Dr. Exner named
were:
1. The dancers must be free
from personal contact.
2. Women must observe propriety and modesty in dress.
3. Chivalry must be men's constant aim.
4. Women must maintain a continual attitude of modesty.
"Spooning," said Dr. Exner, "is
a violation of the first principles of
chivalry. It lowers respect for
women, and it helps to break down
woman's only protection, her reserve and modesty. It is a misdirection of affection and a lowering
of love.
"A college man cannot afford to
spoon. Promiscuous spooning demoralizes the powers of concentration and application, so important
to a young man who would be successful in life. It exercises a demoralizing influence on intellectuality."

Chess Tournament Going Slowly.

The chess tournament, which has
been in progress a little more than
a month, is about half over. 0. B.
Helfrich is the leading player, having won every game so far.
Play is progressing slowly. The
same condition existed last year,
but it was hoped that this season the
men would be more enthusiastic and
that they would play their games
more quickly. At the present rate
of progression, it seems that the
contest is likely to continue through
more than the usual time.

EVERY SUNDAY AT 5 O'CLOCK

He Meant Well.

A gentleman who had married
his cook was giving a dinner party
and between the courses the good
lady sat with her hands spread on
the table cloth.
Suddenly the burr of conversation ceased and in the silence that
followed a young man on the right
of his hostess said pleasantly:
"Awful pause !"
"Yes, they may be," said the oldtime cook, with heightened color,
"and yours would be like them if
you had done half my work."—

Alumni Committee Sends Letter of Congratulation on Operation—Has
Slight Chance for Recovery.

There has been no decided change
in Bob Layfield's condition since his
operation. Dr. Baer, who performed the operation, stated that he
found the spinal cord badly mashed,
but not entirely cut. Although he
did not seen very optimistic about
Bob's chance for recovery, he said
that there was a chance.
At a recent meeting of the alumni
athletic advisers, Mr. Theodore E.
Straus moved that the advisers send
Bob some flowers. The motion was
carried unanimously and the chairman, Mr. Gustav Stewart, was directed to buy the flowers. The following letter was sent with the
flowers:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 25, 1915.

MR, ROBERT LAYFIELD,
1007 Park Place,
Wilmington, Del.
DEAR LAYFIELD:
At a meeting of the Athletic Alumni
Committee of the Johns Hopkins University, it was learned with great pleasure that you are progressing so well
and we all look forward to your recovery.
It must be a great gratification to you
to know that your courage and cheerfulness will always stand out as an example to the future generations of Hopkins students, and your nobility will ever
be an incentive to follow.
We know you will recover, because
your indomitable nerve will assist you,
and we look forward to the day when
you will return to your alma mater,
whose portals could receive no nobler
son. In appreciation of our love and
admiration for you, we send you these
few flowers, which bear our best wishes.
Yours very truly,
GUSTAV L. STEWART,
Chairman.

University for the summer in educational psychology. One of the

the psychology of adolescence. A
similar invitation was also received
by Dr. Baldwin from Pennsylvania
State College and the University of

JUNIORS DEFEAT SENIOR TEAM
REMEMBER THE
Class of 1916 Wins Interclass Debate
Thos. J.Tingley's Rebuttal a Feature.
Steinbach Wins Adams Medal.

ANNUAL CONCERT and DANCE

The eighteenth annual interclass
debate was won by the juniors on
Friday night in McCoy Hall. The
Adams medal for public speaking
was awarded to Alexander Alan
Steinbach.
The first speaker in the Adams
contest was Roger Clarence Heimer, who delivered Lodge's "Our
Navy at Santiago." Heimer spoke
in a clear and emphatic voice, and
on the whole made a very good impression. Alexander Alan Steinbach, who followed him, showed a
greater familiarity with the finer
points of public speaking, and his
selection, Senator Thurston's speech
on "The Monroe Doctrine," enabled
him to use his very effective voice
to the best advantage. Charles
Webster Chesley, the last speaker,
gave Holmes'"The Soldier's Faith"
in a manner which, while not as
striking as Steinbach's, showed evidences of careful preparation.
The subject of the debate between
the seniors and juniors was, "Resolved, That a policy of colonial
expansion is desirable for a modern
State."
The Class of 1915, whose team
was composed of Joseph T. Bartlett, Jr., Charles S. Weech, .Avra
M. Warren (chairman) and Millard Eiseman (alternate), with
Moses Baroway as adviser, upheld
the affirmative.
The negative was defended by
the Class of 1916, represented by
Alfred Niles, Jr., Harrison C. Coffin, Thomas T. Tingley (chairman)
and Dorsey Richardson (alternate),
with Clarence W. McDowell as adviser.
The debate was opened by Mr.
Bartlett, who gave a careful explanation of the subject and outlined
the affirmative's plan of attack. The
first speaker on the negative was
Mr. Coffin, who, with very little introduction, plunged into the subject
and developed his points in a clear
and emphatic manner. Mr. Weech,
the second speaker on the affirmative, showed a thorough knowledge
of the subject. He was followed
by Mr. Niles, the second speaker
on the negative, who briefly and
plainly completed the arguments of
his side and presented a summary
of their entire position.
As rebuttal for the affirmative,
Mr. Warren attacked the arguments of the opposing side in a
clever manner, which pleased the
audience. Mr. Tingley; the closing
speaker, knew his subject and presented his facts and counter-argu-

IN FAVOR OF ARMED CITIZENRY

COTILLON TO BE GALA AFFAIR

Pres. Goodnow Approves Suggestion of
Pres. Hibben of Princeton that Students Receive Military Training.

Second Dance to Last Until Twelvethirty----President and Mrs. Goodnow Will Attend Event.

Military training for students in
American universities and colleges
is favored by President Goodnow.
In a letter sent to the New York
Times, he advocates the suggestion
made by President Hibben, of
Princeton, and says that this suggestion is quite in line with the idea
of "a citizenry trained in arms,"
voiced by President Wilson.
President Goodnow's letter was
as follows:
"I have your letter of January 13,
relative to the suggestion made by
President Hibben that military
training should be introduced into
the University. I personally approve
of the suggestion, believing that in
such a way we should aid in providing for the defense of the country without resort to a large regular army. I feel that this suggestion is quite in line with the idea of
'a citizenry trained in arms,' voiced
by President Wilson.

The second cotillon of the season, which will be held on the evening of Friday, February 12, promises to be a most gala occasion. All
of the devices which, in conjunction with the presence of a certain
orchestra leader not unknown to
fame, have combined to make past
cotillons successful, will be in operation on this eventful night, while,
if rumor is to be credited, there
will be added certain innovations
calculated to make the character of
the entertainment even more distinctive than usual.
The most interesting deviation
from the cotillons of the past will
be the presence of President Goodnow, who, with Mrs. Goodnow, has
consented to lend this very official
recognition to the occasion. The
President has warned the committee, however, that his acceptance of
their invitation is conditional, as he
is unwilling to exhibit publicly his
rendition of the deceptive fox-trot.
Even on these disappointing terms,
however, the acceptance of the invitation is regarded as a precedent
that may go down to future years
of terpsichorean artists yet unborn.
As was the case at the opening
dance of the season, the cotillon
will begin at 8.30, and continue till
half-past twelve, indicating that the
triumph of the Board in securing
an extension of the time limit for
the last affair was by no means a
temporary one. Supper will be
served at i i o'clock, in accordance
with the usual practice, and will
be followed by a continuance of the
"joy unconfined" that, since time
immemorial, has graced all similar
occasions.
It is particularly desired that,
since the time limit has been extended, all who plan to attend the
cotillon will come early and leave
promptly at the closing hour. Such
a course of action in respect to the
latter stipulation will undoubtedly
meet with the high favor of the
numerous gentlemen in waiting
whose task it is to close up the
building when the last belated reveller has departed.

"FRANK

J.

GOODNOW,

"President Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md."
The New York Times received
many letters from noted educators
throughout the country, asked by
that newspaper to give their views
on the subject.
President Goodnow was among
those who approved the suggestion
of President Hibben, of Princeton.
Dr. Hibben, in his letter to the
Times, says:
"Military strength which is available but not visible, and therefore incapable of ostentatious display, will
enable us to meet any critical emergency that may arise, and at the
same time protect us from the domination of a military .caste and a military policy. This plan of intensive
training of our college men does not
in any way tend to increase our
standing army."
This is not the first time Dr.
Goodnow has advocated college athletic training. It will be recalled
that at the opening reception of the
Young Men's Christian Association
last October, President Goodnow
won favor by announcing himself
a convert to athletics.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
MARSHALL SAILS FOR THE WAR
Despite Failure of His First Attempt
He Finally Leaves on Lusitania
to Enlist With Allies.

Julian Marshall, Hopkins graduate, member of the championship
1913 lacrosse team and assistant lacrosse coach, has left for the front.
Mr. Marshall, after being detained
by the Baltimore Custom House officials and prevented from leaving
on the Vulga, finally sailed on January 30 on the Lusitania.
The captain of the Vulga, in order to assist Mr. Marshall in carrying out his plans to join the English army, agreed to hire him as
purser for the trip to England in
consideration of the nominal salary
of one shilling a month. Mr. Marshall was ready to sail on the Vulga
last Tuesday morning, when the
customs officials noticed that the
purser was to receive practically no
salary.
They investigated, and
learning that Mr. Marshall's sole
object in sailing was to join the
English army, they refused him
passage. Consequently, the Vulga
had to sail a day late, and without
the prospective soldier.
He had volunteered after the outbreak of the war to join the Canadian expeditionary forces, but
they would only accept the services
of bona fide Canadians. Mr. Marshall, though born in the United
States, and though he has lived most
of his life here, is of English family, and is himself a registered English subject; therefore, the unsuccessful outcome of his attempts only
made him more determined to go
and fight for England.
Mr. Marshall expects to go directly to London, where he will stay
with relatives. There he will present letters of introduction and
recommendation to several high
military officials, after which at
least six months' training at one of
the officers' training schools will be
necessary before he can hope to see
service at the front; but unless there
is an unexpected turn of affairs, the
war will then still be in progress
and he will have a chance to fight
for his country.
On January' 23, after the freshman-sophomore track meet, Mr.
Marshall practiced with the lacrosse
team and performed his regular
duties as assistant coach. He has
shown marked determination to
carry out his plans and is extremely
optimistic about his venture, having made promises to many of his
friends to bring them back German
helmets as souvenirs.
While his many Hopkins friends
will miss him, they are all proud
of his nerve and determination and
wish him the best of success in attaining the goal of his ambitions.

HULLABALOO WORK PROGRESSES

LECTURES ON POLITICAL THEORY

1915 Board Has Much Copy, Including
Jokes and Poems - Business Department Needs More "Ads."

Prof.Dunning,Schouler Lecturer,Tells of
Burke, Mette, von Holler, Bentham
and Rusten—Two More Talks.

During the last few weeks, work
has been progressing with some
rapidity on the 1915 Hullabaloo.
At each weekly meeting the editors
have had a quantity of material to
read. A large number of original
articles, including jokes, sketches
and poems, has been reviewed by
the Board and reserved for future
use.
The photographic department has
made great progress during the last
month. All of the class pictures
have been taken; the Hullabaloo
Board's picture, THE NEws-LETTER
Board, some of the fraternities and
several other groups have also been
taken.
Mr. Baker, '15, wishes the pictures to be taken as soon as possible, because the sooner the proof
is in the hands of the photographer
the sooner he can give it to the
engravers, and in this way the best
possible results can be obtained for
the cuts that are to appear in the
Hullabaloo.
The pictures of the spring teams
cannot be taken yet, but as soon as
the teams get out of doors the photographer will be called into service. Most of the individual pictures of the members of the senior
class have been taken, but there are
still some delinquents. If all of
these pictures are not in by the first
of March the Board does not propose to hold up the edition for the
tardy seniors.
The underclasses have not as yet
handed in very much material that
might be used. There is very little
time left and all articles have to be
sanctioned by the Board before they
appear in the book.
As has been stated before, the
Board this year is going to have a
certain number of books printed and
n,o more. In order to be sure of
getting a book each man should
sign one of the subscription blanks
that any of the class presidents will
furnish. By paying- before February 25, 1915, fifty cents can be
saved.
The advertising manager announces that the $450 mark has
been passed. To make the book a
complete success, more than a thousand dollars' worth is required. If
each man in the University would
get one ad, the goal desired could be
reached. A liberal commission of
20 per cent, is paid on all advertisements. The firms who have posters
on the Hullabaloo wall should be
patronized. The men who expect
to get out a year book during the
next few years should try to throw
trade to these firms, in this way
gaining their "good will" and perhaps an advertisement for their
own book.

• Prof. William A. Dunning of
Columbia University delivered on
last Monday and Tuesday in McCoy Hall the first of his series of
lectures under the James Schouler
Foundation on the general subject
of "Early Phases of Nineteenth
Century Political Theory."
The topic of Monday's lecture
was "Conservative and Reactionary
Doctrine," while that discussed on
Tuesday was "British Utilitarianism." The method of treatment
was very comprehensive, for instead of merely generalizing, Dr.
Dunning considered intimately the
work and thought of the leading
minds of the period.
The two great movements of the
dawn of the nineteenth century
were the growth of nationalities,
and the rise of written constitutions. Opposed to these innovations there were, however, throughout Europe a number of reactionaries, conspicuously Edmund Burke
in England, Joseph Mette in
France, and Ludwig von Holler in
Germany.
There was not one of the three
who believed in the rights of the
people as they were being asserted
in the revolutions. Burke boldly
attacks them in his "Reflections on
the French Revolution," while
Mette is almost mediaeval in
thought. Von Holler's philosophy
is of a different type. To his mind
the only free man is he who depends on no one, but these persons
gather around them dependents who
form the State. Monarchy is thus
the earliest form of society. When
all Europe was ringing with the
Rights of Man and the Contract
Theory, nothing could have been
more reactionary than the opinions
of these men and their disciples.
A different group of philosophers
was considered on Tuesday by Professor Dunning; a group whose
chief exponents were Jeremy Bentham and his pupil John Rusten.
Utilitarianism, or the greatest good
for the greatest number, was the
doctrine expounded by them. Naturally they were opposed to the
general views of the time, for they
held that "the essence of the State
is merely the habit of conformity."
"Yet, whatever we may think of
utilitarianism," Dr. Dunning concludes, "it is refreshing amidst the
other theories of the time."
There are still two more lectures
of the series which will be delivered
on Monday and Tuesday, February i and 2; the topics being "The
Philosophy of Constitutionalism"
and "The Philosophy of Nationalism."

TRACK SQUAD STRENGTHENED

THE PANAMA LECTURE POPULAR

Men Getting into Shape for Heavy Indoor
Schedule--Hopkins to Be Represented in Important Meets.

Record Crowd Taxed McCoy Hall to
Hear Mr. Fisher Lecture— Featured
by Excellent Stereopticon Views.

The strength of the track squad
was greatly augmented last week
by the appearance of two of last
year's stars, who up to this time
had been unable to practice with
the squad. The squad is unusually
large now, though composed mostly of "green" material. The men,
however, are working regularly and
are fast getting into shape for the
hard indoor season, which will begin Saturday, February 13, with
the George Washington games. It
is proable that a comparatively
small number of men will be sent to
this first meet, as it is not to be a
very large affair. The principal
event for Hopkins will be a one-mile
relay race with Catholic University.
On the other hand, a large team
will be entered in the Fifth Regiment games, held here the following week. There will be at least
two relay races for Hopkins, in addition to the regular open events.
An important new feature of these
games will be a South Atlantic intercollegiate one-mile relay, in which
teams will be entered by Virginia,
Georgetown, Richmond University,
Washington and Lee, Hopkins, and
likely other members of the association. Among the colleges sending
teams to this meet, Princeton and
Pennsylvania figure prominently.
The next week (February 27)
a large team will be sent to the
Georgetown games at Washington.
As Hopkins won this annual contest last year, they have a reputation to live up to. Somewhat later,
a relay team will be sent to take
part in the Meadowbrook meet at
Philadelphia.
Owing to their victory last spring,
Hopkins has been raised another
class in the Penn Relays. They
now stand in Class I, with Columbia, Syracuse, Ohio State, Virginia and Georgetown. The next
step is into the championships.

To Mr. Frederick Vining Fisher
falls the honor of being the most
popular lecturer of the year. His
illustrated lecture on "The PanamaPacific Exposition" last Wednesday
afternoon brought out a crowd
which strained the capacity of McCoy Hall. Before he had begun
to speak it was necessary to lock
the doors in order to prevent overcrowding of the building.
Known as lecturer, author and
traveler, Mr. Fisher has been enlisted as manager of the Bureau of
Lectures of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition. In this role
he is endeavoring to interpret
America, to open a vision of the
greatness of our continent, to disclose its scenic beauties, and, not
least of all, to awaken in his hearers the desire to attend this year
the two expositions in the West.
Westward by means of the stereopticon and amid a seemingly irrepressible flow of ultrapoetic description Mr. Fisher took his audience
from Colorado, seven times the size
of Switzerland, and ten times as
beautiful, to the Grand Canyon in
Arizona. Thence he led the way
across prairies, rich in grain, to
the Yellowstone Park, America's
playground, where he featured the
Old Faithful geyser, "old when
Adam was a boy." Then, in picture, he showed the Chasm of the
Yellowstone, the Cascades, and, at
last, California, the land of great
trees, of the palm and poppy; the
land of perpetual summer, yet from
whose valleys "winters are ever seen
hovering on the peaks."
It is here that two expositions are
to be held this year, to celebrate,
not a national, but an international
event. One will be at San Diego,
the other at San Francisco. But
Mr. Fisher pointed out that it is
to the latter, held in the City of
Dreams, that all eyes are turned,
for, as lie said, it bids fair to rival
Engineers to Meet Friday.
all such efforts of the past.

NATURAL LIGHT IN GILMAN HALL

MUSICIANS ARE IN GOOD SHAPE

An Improved System of Daylight Illumination Will Cut Down Amount of
Electricity Used for Lighting.

Singers and Instrumentalists Holding

and Town Concerts to Be Given.

One thing which impresses every
visitor to Gilman Hall is the splendid natural illumination of the
building. Every nook of the reading-room is flooded with light; offices and classrooms are bright and
cheery, and even the blind corridor
in the basement is not without its
quota of light, which comes through
the postoffice windows.
This is in distinct contrast with
architecture of earlier days. The
same contrast can be seen between
the City Hall and Court House in
this city. An abundance of artificial illumination is necessary in all
the passageways of the City Hall,
whereas, if there were no electric
lights or gas at all in the corridors
of the Court House, one's way
could be readily found. In our
own case this is all the more remarkable because colonial houses
are not famed for their illumination. If one were copying strictly
in this particular a public building
or residence of colonial times, there

The Board of Managers of the
Musical Clubs have been busy during the past week completing arrangements for the McCoy Hall
concert, which will be given on
Tuesday, February 9.
Several hundred tickets have been
mailed to members of the faculty
and alumni from whom the Board
expects assistance. All members of
both clubs have been given tickets
to distribute. Tickets will also be
on sale at the University postoffice.
The price of the ticket (one dollar) also includes the dance which
follows the concert.
The leaders of both clubs have
been holding rehearsals daily and
the indications are that the clubs
will be in excellent condition to give
the first concert of the season,
which will be held on February 3
at the Phipps Psychiatric Clinic of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital. The
present plan of the leaders is that
all members of both clubs who hope
to take the trips must be present at
this concert and by the merits of
the work of the men at this concert
the squad will be picked to go to
Western Maryland.
On February 5, a concert will be
given at Western Maryland Col-,
lege at Westminster, where some
attractive methods of advertising
have been tried out.
The McCoy Hall concert, coming
as it does on the ninth, directly
preceded by these three preliminary
engagements, should be a success.
in every particular.
On February 16, a concert will
be given in this city at Odd Fellows' Hall, under the auspices of
the Girls' Guild of the First English Lutheran Church. An informal dance will follow' the concert.
Tickets may be secured at fifty cents
each from P. K. Bell.
Several more trips and local
concerts will be included in the
schedule.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 1, 1915.

JOHNS HOPKINS WILL HAVE AN
EHXIBIT AT SAN FRANCISCO FAIR

NEW MACHINERY INSTALLED IN
POWER PLANT AT HOMEWOOD

It was announced last week that
Johns Hopkins will send an exhibit
to the Panama-Pacific Exposition.
It will consist of drawings, made
by one of the consulting architects,
of the new Homewood buildings
and of the whole plans of the future
home of the University.
In addition to these drawings,
several pictures of historical interest
to the University will be exhibited.
Among these is a photograph of the
original deed of Homewood, which
was discovered lying loose in a record book at Annapolis several years
ago. A photograph of this deed
was presented to the University
about five years ago by Mrs. Hester
Dorsey Richardson, and has since
hung in the President's private
office.
The Hopkins exhibit will be hung
in the Maryland Building, along
with the historical exhibit which
will be housed there. It is interesting to note that the Maryland
Building is an exact replica of
Homewood, which is considered to
be the most perfect typical colonial
mansion in the State.

The new power plant at Homewood is now in operation. During
the past week the temporary lines
which had been run in by the Gas
and Electric Company were removed and the lighting of the buildings, together with the running of
the machinery in the shop, was
taken over entirely by current generated in the power-house.
An interesting feature of the
change was the charging of the
storage batteries. These batteries
completely fill a room which is
about fifteen by thirty-five feet and
they are used to meet any need for
current which may arise at night—
it being planned to run the dynamos
only during the day. In order to
give these batteries their initial
charge, it was necessary to run the
Westinghouse generator continuously for thirty-six hours.
During this time both the turbine
and the dynamos behaved splendidly, and those in charge were well
pleased with the results of the run.
Work on the installation of the
Corliss, Diesel, Foss and other special engines for test purposes is
well under way, and they will soon
be ready for use.
The ice machine is now being installed in the south end of Machinery Hall, while in the other end
many of the motors and other electrical apparatus have been put in
place.
The testing machines for the
civil engineering department are
in the "L" wing of the Hall and
are now ready for use.
Progress made thus far in equipping this building indicates that it
will not be long before the department of engineering is completely
settled in its new building.

SPOONING CONDEMNED
BY UNIVERSITY SPEAKER

Dancing and spooning as pastimes for college students were dealt
a hard blow by Dr. M. J. Exner, a
- member of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christion Association, when he addressed
three hundred men of the University of Washington recently, on "A
Rational Fight for Self-Mastery in
the Sphere of Sex."
"The modern dance is inexpedient," he said. "There are certain
conditions under which I would
consider dancing proper, but unless
these are observed, you have no
right to indulge in dancing."
The conditions Dr. Exner named
were:
1. The dancers must be free
from personal contact.
2. Women must observe propriety and modesty in dress.
3. Chivalry must be men's constant aim.
4. Women must maintain a continual attitude of modesty.
"Spooning," said Dr. Exner, "is
a violation of the first principles of
chivalry. It lowers respect for
women, and it helps to break down
woman's only protection, her reserve and modesty. It is a misdirection of affection and a lowering
of love.
"A college man cannot afford to
spoon. Promiscuous spooning demoralizes the powers of concentration and application, so important
to a young man who would be successful in life. It exercises a demoralizing influence on intellectuality."

Chess Tournament Going Slowly.

The chess tournament, which has
been in progress a little more than
a month, is about half over. 0. B.
Helfrich is the leading player, having won every game so far.
Play is progressing slowly. The
same condition existed last year,
but it was hoped that this season the
men would be more enthusiastic and
that they would play their games
more quickly. At the present rate
of progression, it seems that the
contest is likely to continue through
more than the usual time.

EVERY SUNDAY AT 5 O'CLOCK

He Meant Well.

A gentleman who had married
his cook was giving a dinner party
and between the courses the good
lady sat with her hands spread on
the table cloth.
Suddenly the burr of conversation ceased and in the silence that
followed a young man on the right
of his hostess said pleasantly:
"Awful pause !"
"Yes, they may be," said the oldtime cook, with heightened color,
"and yours would be like them if
you had done half my work."—

Alumni Committee Sends Letter of Congratulation on Operation—Has
Slight Chance for Recovery.

There has been no decided change
in Bob Layfield's condition since his
operation. Dr. Baer, who performed the operation, stated that he
found the spinal cord badly mashed,
but not entirely cut. Although he
did not seen very optimistic about
Bob's chance for recovery, he said
that there was a chance.
At a recent meeting of the alumni
athletic advisers, Mr. Theodore E.
Straus moved that the advisers send
Bob some flowers. The motion was
carried unanimously and the chairman, Mr. Gustav Stewart, was directed to buy the flowers. The following letter was sent with the
flowers:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 25, 1915.

MR, ROBERT LAYFIELD,
1007 Park Place,
Wilmington, Del.
DEAR LAYFIELD:
At a meeting of the Athletic Alumni
Committee of the Johns Hopkins University, it was learned with great pleasure that you are progressing so well
and we all look forward to your recovery.
It must be a great gratification to you
to know that your courage and cheerfulness will always stand out as an example to the future generations of Hopkins students, and your nobility will ever
be an incentive to follow.
We know you will recover, because
your indomitable nerve will assist you,
and we look forward to the day when
you will return to your alma mater,
whose portals could receive no nobler
son. In appreciation of our love and
admiration for you, we send you these
few flowers, which bear our best wishes.
Yours very truly,
GUSTAV L. STEWART,
Chairman.

Dr. Baldwin for Summer School.

Dr. Baldwin, of Swarthmore College, has been asked to accept a
professorship in Johns Hopkins
University for the summer in educational psychology. One of the
courses will be a graduate course in
the psychology of adolescence. A
similar invitation was also received
by Dr. Baldwin from Pennsylvania
State College and the University of
Tennessee.
